question:
Given:
p1: Blue is a common color.
p2: Yellow is a common color.
p3: \sqrt{3}  is irrational.
p4: 5 is irrational.

Symbolize the following propositions:
(1) Blue and yellow are both common colors.
(2) Either \sqrt{3} or 5 is irrational.
(3) Exactly one of \sqrt{3} and 5 is irrational.

Specify that only &,||,~ can be used for this question.
Please format your answers as [[ ];[ ];[ ]], where each bracketed section contains the corresponding logical expression for each proposition.
needle: Propositions are represented using p1, p2, ..., pn.
Let p1 be a proposition, the compound proposition "not p1" is represented as ~p1.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 and p2" is represented as p1&p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 or p2" is represented as p1||p2.
title: Propositional Logic Formalization
rule_content:
Propositions are represented using p1, p2, ..., pn.
Let p1 be a proposition, the compound proposition "not p1" is represented as ~p1.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 and p2" is represented as p1&p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 or p2" is represented as p1||p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "if p1, then p2" is represented as p1=::>p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 if and only if p2" is represented as p1=p2.
A single proposition and proposition constants can be called a formula.
Formulas are represented using F1, F2, ..., Fn.
If F1 is a formula, then ~F1 is also a formula.
If F1 and F2 are formulas, then F1&F2, F1||F2, F1=::>F2, F1=F2 are also formulas.
Level A Formula: The most basic proposition unit, without logical connectives or nested structures.
Level B Formula: A formula containing one logical connective, and the connected two propositions are both Level A formulas.For example, p1.
Level C Formula: A formula containing nested logical connectives and at least one Level B formula.For example, ~p1.
Other levels of logic follow by analogy; when higher than Level Z, they are classified as Z+n (n≥1).For example, ~(~p1).
True assignment of a proposition: A proposition p1 is assigned as ✓, indicating that p1 is true.
False assignment of a proposition: A proposition p1 is assigned as x, indicating that p1 is false.
True assignment of a formula: If the formula is (~p1&~p2&~p3)||(p1&p2), then x|x|x,✓|✓|x are true assignments of the formula.
False assignment of a formula: If the formula is (~p1&~p2&~p3)||(p1&p2), then x|x|✓,x|✓|✓ are false assignments of the formula.
For p1=::>p2, only ✓|x is a false assignment of the formula.
A formula that is true under all assignments is called a Truth Formula.
A formula that is false under all assignments is called a Falsehood Formula.
Recursive definition of formulas: Any formula containing nested logical connectives can be decomposed recursively to obtain its subformulas and their logical connective structures.
Priority of logical connectives: The priority of logical connectives from high to low is as follows: ~ (not), & (and), || (or), =::> (if...then), = (if and only if).
Without parentheses, operations are performed according to priority.
Equivalence of formulas: Two formulas are equivalent if they have the same truth value under all assignments.
Equivalent formulas can be interchanged.
Simplification of formulas: Formulas can be simplified through logical rules to obtain a more concise form without changing the truth value of the formula.

Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 if and only if p2" is represented as p1=p2.
A single proposition and proposition constants can be called a formula.
Formulas are represented using F1, F2, ..., Fn.
If F1 is a formula, then ~F1 is also a formula.
If F1 and F2 are formulas, then F1&F2, F1||F2, F1=::>F2, F1=F2 are also formulas.
Level A Formula: The most basic proposition unit, without logical connectives or nested structures.
Level B Formula: A formula containing one logical connective, and the connected two propositions are both Level A formulas.For example, p1.
Level C Formula: A formula containing nested logical connectives and at least one Level B formula.For example, ~p1.
Other levels of logic follow by analogy; when higher than Level Z, they are classified as Z+n (n≥1).For example, ~(~p1).
True assignment of a proposition: A proposition p1 is assigned as ✓, indicating that p1 is true.
False assignment of a proposition: A proposition p1 is assigned as x, indicating that p1 is false.
True assignment of a formula: If the formula is (~p1&~p2&~p3)||(p1&p2), then x|x|x,✓|✓|x are true assignments of the formula.
False assignment of a formula: If the formula is (~p1&~p2&~p3)||(p1&p2), then x|x|✓,x|✓|✓ are false assignments of the formula.
For p1=::>p2, only ✓|x is a false assignment of the formula.
A formula that is true under all assignments is called a Truth Formula.
A formula that is false under all assignments is called a Falsehood Formula.
Recursive definition of formulas: Any formula containing nested logical connectives can be decomposed recursively to obtain its subformulas and their logical connective structures.
Priority of logical connectives: The priority of logical connectives from high to low is as follows: ~ (not), & (and), || (or), =::> (if...then), = (if and only if).
Without parentheses, operations are performed according to priority.
Equivalence of formulas: Two formulas are equivalent if they have the same truth value under all assignments.
Equivalent formulas can be interchanged.
Simplification of formulas: Formulas can be simplified through logical rules to obtain a more concise form without changing the truth value of the formula.

### Question:
Convert the following propositions into symbolic formulas:
"p1 if and only if p2 is false."

Please format your answer as [[ ]], where the part in parentheses contains the corresponding logical expression of the proposition.

### Answer:
[[p1=~p2]]

### Question:
Determine the level, type of **p1**.

A. Truth Formula, B. Falsehood Formula, C. Neither.

For levels, answers should be given as a single letter from A to Z or Z+n (where n is a number greater than or equal to 1). For Type, the answer should give the options in A/B/C above. 

The format of the overall answer is [[level];[A/B/C]].

### Answer:
[[A];[C]]

### Question:
Find the truth values and falsity values of the following formula.
Formula: p1 =::> ~p2

The answer format is [[T:...];[F:...]]. If there are multiple values in T(F), they should be separated by commas (,).

### Answer:
[[T:✓|x,x|x,x|✓];[F:✓|✓]]

2. Apply the given logical operations or reasoning patterns.
3. Ensure your output is formatted according to the specified notation and symbols.

### Logic Rule:

Propositions are represented using p1, p2, ..., pn.
Let p1 be a proposition, the compound proposition "not p1" is represented as ~p1.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 and p2" is represented as p1&p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 or p2" is represented as p1||p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "if p1, then p2" is represented as p1=::>p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 if and only if p2" is represented as p1=p2.
A single proposition and proposition constants can be called a formula.
Formulas are represented using F1, F2, ..., Fn.
If F1 is a formula, then ~F1 is also a formula.
If F1 and F2 are formulas, then F1&F2, F1||F2, F1=::>F2, F1=F2 are also formulas.
Level A Formula: The most basic proposition unit, without logical connectives or nested structures.
Level B Formula: A formula containing one logical connective, and the connected two propositions are both Level A formulas.For example, p1.
Level C Formula: A formula containing nested logical connectives and at least one Level B formula.For example, ~p1.
Other levels of logic follow by analogy; when higher than Level Z, they are classified as Z+n (n≥1).For example, ~(~p1).
True assignment of a proposition: A proposition p1 is assigned as ✓, indicating that p1 is true.
False assignment of a proposition: A proposition p1 is assigned as x, indicating that p1 is false.
True assignment of a formula: If the formula is (~p1&~p2&~p3)||(p1&p2), then x|x|x,✓|✓|x are true assignments of the formula.
False assignment of a formula: If the formula is (~p1&~p2&~p3)||(p1&p2), then x|x|✓,x|✓|✓ are false assignments of the formula.
For p1=::>p2, only ✓|x is a false assignment of the formula.
A formula that is true under all assignments is called a Truth Formula.
A formula that is false under all assignments is called a Falsehood Formula.
Recursive definition of formulas: Any formula containing nested logical connectives can be decomposed recursively to obtain its subformulas and their logical connective structures.
Priority of logical connectives: The priority of logical connectives from high to low is as follows: ~ (not), & (and), || (or), =::> (if...then), = (if and only if).
Without parentheses, operations are performed according to priority.
Equivalence of formulas: Two formulas are equivalent if they have the same truth value under all assignments.
Equivalent formulas can be interchanged.
Simplification of formulas: Formulas can be simplified through logical rules to obtain a more concise form without changing the truth value of the formula.

### Question:
Convert the following propositions into symbolic formulas:
"p1 if and only if p2 is false."

Please format your answer as [[ ]], where the part in parentheses contains the corresponding logical expression of the proposition.

### Answer:
[[p1=~p2]]

### Question:
Determine the level, type of **p1**.

A. Truth Formula, B. Falsehood Formula, C. Neither.

For levels, answers should be given as a single letter from A to Z or Z+n (where n is a number greater than or equal to 1). For Type, the answer should give the options in A/B/C above. 

The format of the overall answer is [[level];[A/B/C]].

### Answer:
[[A];[C]]

Find the truth values and falsity values of the following formula.
Formula: p1 =::> ~p2

The answer format is [[T:...];[F:...]]. If there are multiple values in T(F), they should be separated by commas (,).

### Answer:
[[T:✓|x,x|x,x|✓];[F:✓|✓]]

(1)~(~p1&p2)||~p3
(2)(~p2||p3)&(p1=::>p2)
(3)(p1=::>p2)&(~(p1&p3)||p1)
The answer format is [[F:...];[F:...];[F:...]].If there are multiple values in F, they should be separated by commas (,).For example [[F:x|x|x];[F:✓|✓|✓];[F:x|x|x,✓|✓|✓]]

### Answer:
response:
[[F:x|✓|x,x|✓|✓];[F:✓|x|x];[F:✓|x|x]]

### Question:
Simplify the following formula:
p1 = p2 & p2 = p3 & ~(p1||p2)=p3

### Answer:
[[~p1=p2&p2=p3]]

(1)p1=::>p2=&p3
(2)p1=&(p2||p3)
A, B, Yes, No. If the two formulas are equivalent, the answer should be A; otherwise, B.

### Answer:
A

Determine the equivalence or non-equivalence of the original formula and each of the simplified formulas. For equivalent pairs, only the number of the pair (e.g., 1 and 2, not 2 and 1).

1. ~(p1 & p2)
2. ~p1 || ~p2

A. Yes, Yes, B. Yes, No, C. No, Yes, D. No, No

### Answer:
B

Determine the equivalence or non-equivalence of the original formula and each of the simplified formulas. For equivalent pairs, only the number of the pair (e.g., 1 and 2, not 2 and 1).

2. ~(p1 && p2)

A. Yes, Yes, B. Yes, No, C. No, Yes, D. No, No

3. Ensure your output is formatted according to the specified notation and symbols.

### Logic Rule:

Propositions are represented using p1, p2, ..., pn.
Let p1 be a proposition, the compound proposition "not p1" is represented as ~p1.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 and p2" is represented as p1&p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 or p2" is represented as p1||p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "if p1, then p2" is represented as p1=::>p2.
Let p1 and p2 be two propositions, the compound proposition "p1 if and only if p2" is represented as p1=p2.
A single proposition and proposition constants can be called a formula.
Formulas are represented using F1, F2, ..., Fn.
If F1 is a formula, then ~F1 is also a formula.
If F1 and F2 are formulas, then F1&F2, F1||F2, F1=::>F2, F1=F2 are also formulas.
Level A Formula: The most basic proposition unit, without logical connectives or nested structures.
Level B Formula: A formula containing one logical connective, and the connected two propositions are both Level A formulas.For example, p1.
Level C Formula: A formula containing nested logical connectives and at least one Level B formula.For example, ~p1.
Other levels of logic follow by analogy; when higher than Level Z, they are classified as Z+n (n≥1).For example, ~(~p1).
True assignment of a proposition: A proposition p1 is assigned as ✓, indicating that p1 is true.
False assignment of a proposition: A proposition p1 is assigned as x, indicating that p1 is false.
True assignment of a formula: If the formula is (~p1&~p2&~p3)||(p1&p2), then x|x|x,✓|✓|x are true assignments of the formula.
False assignment of a formula: If the formula is (~p1&~p2&~p3)||(p1&p2), then x|x|✓,x|✓|✓ are false assignments of the formula.
For p1=::>p2, only ✓|x is a false assignment of the formula.
A formula that is true under all assignments is called a Truth Formula.
A formula that is false under all assignments is called a Falsehood Formula.
Recursive definition of formulas: Any formula containing nested logical connectives can be decomposed recursively to obtain its subformulas and their logical connective structures.
Priority of logical connectives: The priority of logical connectives from high to low is as follows: ~ (not), & (and), || (or), =::> (if...then), = (if and only if).
Without parentheses, operations are performed according to priority.
Equivalence of formulas: Two formulas are equivalent if they have the same truth value under all assignments.
Equivalent formulas can be interchanged.
Simplification of formulas: Formulas can be simplified through logical rules to obtain a more concise form without changing the truth value of the formula.

### Question:
Convert the following propositions into symbolic formulas:
"p1 if and only if p2 is false."

Please format your answer as [[ ]], where the part in parentheses contains the corresponding logical expression of the proposition.

### Answer:
[[p1=~p2]]

### Question:
Determine the level, type of **p1**.

A. Truth Formula, B. Falsehood Formula, C. Neither.

For levels, answers should be given as a single letter from A to Z or Z+n (where n is a number greater than or equal to 1). For Type, the answer should give the options in A/B/C above. 

The format of the overall answer is [[level];[A/B/C]].

### Answer:
[[A];[C]]

Formula: p1 =::> ~p2

The answer format is [[T:...];[F:...]]. If there are multiple values in T(F), they should be separated by commas (,).

### Answer:
[[T:✓|x,x|x,x|✓];[F:✓|✓]]

 ~(p1=::>p2)&p2 is a Falsehood Formula,

(1) (p1=::>(p1||p2))&(~(p1=::>p2)&p2)
(2) (p1=::>(p1||p2))||(~(p1=::>p2)&p2)

A. Truth Formula, B. Falsehood Formula, C. Neither.

### Answer:
response:

### Question:

### Answer:
[(p1&~p2)||(p2=&p3):(p1:=::>(p2&~p2))|(~p1=::>(p2&~p2))|(p2=::>(p2=&p3))|(~p2=::>(p2=&p3))|(p1||(&p2))|(~p1||(&p2))|(p2||(=p3))|(~p2||(=p3))]

(3) (~p1&~p2&~p3)||(p1&p2)=~(p1||(~p2&(~p3||p2)));;
(4) (~p1&~p2&~p3)||(p1&p2)=p1&p2;;

### Answer:
(1)

Simplify ~p3 =::> ~(p1&p2).

### Answer:
p3||~(p1&p2)

Person A: Professor Wang is not from Suzhou, he is from Shanghai.
Person B: Professor Wang is not from Shanghai, he is from Suzhou.
Person C: Professor Wang is neither from Shanghai nor from Hangzhou.

After hearing these judgments, Professor Wang chuckled and remarked, "One of you got everything right, one got half right, and one got everything wrong."

q denote "Professor Wang is from Shanghai," 
and r denote "Professor Wang is from Hangzhou."

Person A:!p&q
Person B:p&!q
Person C:!q&!r

Define the following logical expressions for Person A:
B1=!p&q (Person A's statements are entirely correct).
B2=(!p&!q)|(p&q) (Person A's  statements are partially correct).
B3=p&!q (Person A's statements are entirely incorrect).

C1 (Person B's statements are entirely correct).
C2 (Person B's  statements are partially correct).
C3 (Person B's statements are entirely incorrect).

And for Person C:
D1 (Person C's statements are entirely correct).
D2 (Person C's  statements are partially correct).
D3 (Person C's statements are entirely incorrect).

Please provide the corresponding logical expressions. The answer format should be:
[[C1=...];[C2=...];[C3=...];[D1=...];[D2=...];[D3=...]].

needle: - If the principal disjunctive normal form of A includes all 2^n paired conjunctive terms, A is a tautology.
- If the principal disjunctive normal form of A includes no paired conjunctive terms, A is a contradiction.
- If the principal disjunctive normal form of A includes m0, A is a basic formula.
- If the indices i of the paired conjunctive terms included in the principal disjunctive normal form of A are all even, A is an all-even formula.
- If the indices i of the paired conjunctive terms included in the principal disjunctive normal form of A are all odd, A is an all-odd formula.
title: Disjunctive Normal Form and Conjunctive Normal Form
rule_content:
In a simple conjunctive form (simple disjunctive form) containing n propositional variables, if each propositional variable and its negation appear exactly once, and the propositional variables or their negations are arranged in ascending order of subscripts or in lexicographical order, such a simple conjunctive form (simple disjunctive form) is called a paired conjunctive term (paired disjunctive term).
If the true assignment of a paired conjunctive term corresponds to a binary number equal to hexadecimal number i, this paired conjunctive term is denoted as mi (lowercase m). For example, the true assignment of p∧q is 11, and the binary number is 11, corresponding to hexadecimal number 3, denoted as m3.
If the false assignment of a paired disjunctive term corresponds to a binary number equal to hexadecimal number i, this paired disjunctive term is denoted as Mi (uppercase M). For example, the false assignment of ¬p∨¬q∨¬r is 111, and the binary number is 111, corresponding to hexadecimal number 7, denoted as M7.
The disjunctive normal form (conjunctive normal form) consisting of all paired conjunctive terms (paired disjunctive terms) is called the principal disjunctive normal form (principal conjunctive normal form).
Given a formula A containing n propositional variables:
- If the principal disjunctive normal form of A includes all 2^n paired conjunctive terms, A is a tautology.
- If the principal disjunctive normal form of A includes no paired conjunctive terms, A is a contradiction.
- If the principal disjunctive normal form of A includes m0, A is a basic formula.
- If the indices i of the paired conjunctive terms included in the principal disjunctive normal form of A are all even, A is an all-even formula.
- If the indices i of the paired conjunctive terms included in the principal disjunctive normal form of A are all odd, A is an all-odd formula.

### Logic Rule:

In a simple conjunctive form (simple disjunctive form) containing n propositional variables, if each propositional variable and its negation appear exactly once, and the propositional variables or their negations are arranged in ascending order of subscripts or in lexicographical order, such a simple conjunctive form (simple disjunctive form) is called a paired conjunctive term (paired disjunctive term).
If the true assignment of a paired conjunctive term corresponds to a binary number equal to hexadecimal number i, this paired conjunctive term is denoted as mi (lowercase m). For example, the true assignment of p∧q is 11, and the binary number is 11, corresponding to hexadecimal number 3, denoted as m3.
If the false assignment of a paired disjunctive term corresponds to a binary number equal to hexadecimal number i, this paired disjunctive term is denoted as Mi (uppercase M). For example, the false assignment of ¬p∨¬q∨¬r is 111, and the binary number is 111, corresponding to hexadecimal number 7, denoted as M7.
The disjunctive normal form (conjunctive normal form) consisting of all paired conjunctive terms (paired disjunctive terms) is called the principal disjunctive normal form (principal conjunctive normal form).
Given a formula A containing n propositional variables:
- If the principal disjunctive normal form of A includes all 2^n paired conjunctive terms, A is a tautology.
- If the principal disjunctive normal form of A includes no paired conjunctive terms, A is a contradiction.

- If the indices i of the paired conjunctive terms included in the principal disjunctive normal form of A are all odd, A is an all-odd formula.

title: Disjunctive Normal Form and Conjunctive Normal Form
rule_content:
In a simple conjunctive form (simple disjunctive form) containing n propositional variables, if each propositional variable and its negation appear exactly once, and the propositional variables or their negations are arranged in ascending order of subscripts or in lexicographical order, such a simple conjunctive form (simple disjunctive form) is called a paired conjunctive term (paired disjunctive term).
If the true assignment of a paired conjunctive term corresponds to a binary number equal to hexadecimal number i, this paired conjunctive term is denoted as mi (lowercase m). For example, the true assignment of p∧q is 11, and the binary number is 11, corresponding to hexadecimal number 3, denoted as m3.
If the false assignment of a paired disjunctive term corresponds to a binary number equal to hexadecimal number i, this paired disjunctive term is denoted as Mi (uppercase M). For example, the false assignment of ¬p∨¬q∨¬r is 111, and the binary number is 111, corresponding to hexadecimal number 7, denoted as M7.
The disjunctive normal form (conjunctive normal form) consisting of all paired conjunctive terms (paired disjunctive terms) is called the principal disjunctive normal form (principal conjunctive normal form).
Given a formula A containing n propositional variables:
- If the principal disjunctive normal form of A includes all 2^n paired conjunctive terms, A is a tautology.
- If the principal disjunctive normal form of A includes no paired conjunctive terms, A is a contradiction.
- If the principal disjunctive normal form of A includes m0, A is a basic formula.
- If the indices i of the paired conjunctive terms included in the principal disjunctive normal form of A are all even, A is an all-even formula.
- If the indices i of the paired conjunctive terms included in the principal disjunctive normal form of A are all odd, A is an all-odd formula.

Resolution: Suppose simple disjunctive clause C1 = C3 ∨ L, C2 = C4 ∨ L’, then C1 and C2 can be resolved, and it is defined that dispel(C1, C2) = C3 ∨ C4. If it is empty, then dispel(C1, C2) = 0.
title: Resolution
rule_content:
Literal: A propositional variable and its negation are collectively referred to as literals.

Complement: If L is a literal, then the complement of L is denoted as L’. If L = p, then L’ = ¬p; if L = ¬p, then L’ = p.

Resolution: Suppose simple disjunctive clause C1 = C3 ∨ L, C2 = C4 ∨ L’, then C1 and C2 can be resolved, and it is defined that dispel(C1, C2) = C3 ∨ C4. If it is empty, then dispel(C1, C2) = 0.

Resolution Algorithm: The steps to determine if a conjunctive normal form has a satisfying assignment are as follows:
1. Input: Conjunctive normal form S.
2. Output: If S has a satisfying assignment, output “Plausible”; otherwise, output “Implausible”.
3. Steps:
    1. Initialization:
        - Let S0 and S2 be empty sets.
        - Let S1 be the set of all simple disjunctive clauses in S.
    2. Resolve clauses in S0 and S1:
        - For each simple disjunctive clause C1 in S0 and each simple disjunctive clause C2 in S1:
            - If C1 and C2 can be resolved, calculate C = dispel(C1, C2).
            - If C = 0, output “Implausible” and terminate the calculation.
            - If neither S0 nor S1 contains C, add C to S2.
    3. Resolve clauses in S1:
        - For each pair of clauses C1 and C2 in S1:
            - If C1 and C2 can be resolved, calculate C = dispel(C1, C2).
            - If C = 0, output “Implausible” and terminate the calculation.
            - If neither S0 nor S1 contains C, add C to S2.
    4. Check S2:
        - If S2 contains no elements, output “Plausible” and terminate the calculation.
        - Otherwise, add S1 to S0, set S1 to S2, clear S2, and return to step b.

        - Let S1 be the set of all simple disjunctive clauses in S.
    2. Resolve clauses in S0 and S1:
        - For each simple disjunctive clause C1 in S0 and each simple disjunctive clause C2 in S1:
            - If C1 and C2 can be resolved, calculate C = dispel(C1, C2).
            - If C = 0, output “Implausible” and terminate the calculation.
            - If neither S0 nor S1 contains C, add C to S2.
    3. Resolve clauses in S1:
        - For each pair of clauses C1 and C2 in S1:
            - If C1 and C2 can be resolved, calculate C = dispel(C1, C2).
            - If C = 0, output “Implausible” and terminate the calculation.
            - If neither S0 nor S1 contains C, add C to S2.
    4. Check S2:
        - If S2 contains no elements, output “Plausible” and terminate the calculation.
        - Otherwise, add S1 to S0, set S1 to S2, clear S2, and return to step b.

### Question:
Can clauses C1 = ¬p ∨¬q and C2 = q ∨ ¬r be resolved?
A. Yes    B. No

Answer format: [[option]].

### Answer:
[[A]]

### Question:
If C1 = p ∨ ¬q ∨ r and C2 = ¬p ∨ q ∨ ¬r,
then dispel(C1, C2) = ?
Provide the answer in the format [[]],
or [[];[];…] if there are multiple answers.

### Answer:
[[¬q∨r∨q∨¬r];[p∨r∨¬p∨¬r];[p∨¬q∨¬p∨q]]

### Question:

what is the output of the resolution algorithm?

[[Implausible];[2]]

to the respective circuit diagram
[[Input, Output];[Output when circuit is powered and not powered], ...]

### Answer:
Are you asking for a truth table for this expression?

### Question:
No. I am asking for a circuit diagram where the output can represent the truth table for this expression.

### Answer:

Here's a circuit diagram that corresponds to the expression "(p⊻q→r) ≡ (p→r)∧(¬p→r)":

```
// A XOR B
 // Logic Diagram: circ symgxor -I a,b -O y -> https://godoc.org/honnef.co/go/js/dom/canvas#HTMLCanvasElement.Set
% canvas 75 75 0 "AND_GATE" "mydiagram"
  % org 23 -10 10 0
  circ -x I1,a -I2,b c -n x R -s " "
  circ -y I3,I c -n x^ R -s " "
  % org 47 -10 -10 0
  circ -x x I -O y,I c -s " "
  % org 23 10 -10 0
  circ -x I1,a -I2,b c -n y^ R -s "P"
  % org 47 -10 -10 0
  circ -x I3,I c -n y^ R -s "Q"
  % org 23 10 10 0
  circ -x x I -O y,O c -s "R"
% end
```

This circuit diagram represents the logical expression as a series of gates: a XOR gate followed by AND gates. The input is represented by the inputs I1 and I2. The output of the circuit is represented by the output O.

### Question:
 Please state line numbers so that I can direct you to the correct line for your answer.

%% Answer: 
My apologies for the confusion. I provided a circuit diagram with a logic expression "(a XOR b) ≡ (a→ b)∧(¬a→b)" instead of the circuit diagram with a logic expression "(p⊻q→r) ≡ (p→r)∧(¬p→r)". Here's the corrected circuit diagram for the logical expression "(p⊻q→r) ≡ (p→r)∧(¬p→r)" using the same variable symbols:

```
// also XNOR
 // Logic Symbol: SN54108,SN54LS109,SN74108,SN74LS109 -N
 % canvas 70 115 0 "AND_GATE" "mydiagram"
   % org -16 -20 10 0
   circ -x I1,a -I2,b c -n x R -s "XOR"
   % org -16 20 -10 0
   circ -x I3,I c -n x^ R -s "NOT"
   % org 3 -20 -10 0
   circ -x x I -O y,I c -n x^ -s "AND"
   % org -16 20 10 0
   circ -x I1,a -I2,b c -n y^ R -s "P"
   % org 3 20 -10 0
   circ -x I3,I c -n y^ R -s "Q"
   % org -16 20 10 0
   circ -x x

B: p∨r

A SR latch is a circuit consisting of two cross-coupled NOR gates.

Looking at its truth table above, you can see:
where there are two inputs, S and R; 
four outputs: S1, R1, Q, and  identically Q; 
corresponding to:
  positive edge-triggered clock pulse signal,
  negative edge-triggered clock pulse signal.
  Q output is the clock output when S=0, R=1,
  while 
  Q output is the inverse of the clock output when S=1, R=0.

or the box is empty. 

The three boxes have the property that:

*If Box A has a white ball then Box B is usually empty.

*If Box B is empty, then Box C is more likely to have a white ball.

*If Box B has a white ball then Box C is usually not empty.

*Box A in general does not have a white ball when Box C has a white ball.

### Question:
Please provide an example of a mathematical proof of why logical connectives are associated with false.

### Answer:
A logical connective is a symbol or word that connects two statements or propositions to form a new statement. The connectives used in logic are negation (not), conjunction (and), disjunction (or), and implication (if ... then). 

For example, consider the following statement: 

P ∧ Q (P and Q) 

This statement is only true if both P and Q are true. If either P or Q is false, then the whole statement is false. This is because of the way that the logical connectives are defined. Negation is defined as "not true", conjunction is defined as "true if both statements are true", and disjunction is defined as "true if at least one statement is true". 

So, for the statement P ∧ Q to be true, both P and Q must be true. If either P or Q is false, then the whole statement is false. Therefore, the logical connectives are associated with false.

question:
In individual domains limited to (a) and (b) conditions, symbolize the following two propositions:
(1) All humans breathe.
(2) Some people write with their left hand.
Where:
(a) Individual domain D1 is the set of humans.
(b) Individual domain D2 is the universal domain.

(a) 
Let F(x): x breathes.
G(x): x writes with their left hand.
In D1, apart from humans, there is nothing else,
thus (1) symbolizes as? (2) symbolizes as?

(b) 
In D2, besides humans, there are all things, 
so when symbolizing, humans must be separated first. 
Introduce predicate M(x): x is a human. 
In D2, clarify (1) and (2) as follows:
(1) For all individuals in the universe, if the individual is human, then they breathe.
(2) There exists an individual in the universe who writes with their left hand (or more precisely, there exists such an individual who is human and writes with their left hand).

Therefore, (1) symbolizes as?(2) symbolizes as?

Please provide the answers in the format [[];[];[];[]].
needle: "All x in D have property F" is symbolized as AxF(x).
"Some x in D have property F" is symbolized as ExF(x).
"For all x in D, if x has property F, then x has property G" is symbolized as Ax(F(x) ⇒ G(x)).
"Some x in D have both properties F and G" is symbolized as Ex(F(x) & G(x)).
title: Predicate Logic Formalization
rule_content:
Universal Quantifier: Use Ax to denote "for all x".
Existential Quantifier: Use Ex to denote "there exists some x".

Logical Connectives:
Conjunction: Use &
Disjunction: Use |
Implication: Use ⇒
Negation: Use ∼

In general, a predicate P with n (n > 1) individual variables is called an n-ary predicate, denoted as P(x1, x2, ..., xn). When n = 1, P(x) denotes the property P; when n ≥ 2, P(x1, x2, ..., xn) denotes the relationship P among x1, x2, ..., xn.

Predicates without individual variables are called 0-ary predicates. For example, F(a), G(a, b), P(a1, ..., an) are all 0-ary predicates.

Let D be the domain of individuals.
"All x in D have property F" is symbolized as AxF(x).
"Some x in D have property F" is symbolized as ExF(x).
"For all x in D, if x has property F, then x has property G" is symbolized as Ax(F(x) ⇒ G(x)).
"Some x in D have both properties F and G" is symbolized as Ex(F(x) & G(x)).
"For all x, y in D, if x has property F and y has property G, then x and y have relationship H" is symbolized as AxAy(F(x) & F(y) ⇒ H(x, y)).
"For all x in D, if x has property F, then there exists some y with property G such that x and y have relationship H" is symbolized as Ax(F(x) ⇒ Ey(G(y) & H(x, y))).
"There exists some x in D with property F, and for all y in D, if y has property G, then x and y have relationship H" is symbolized as Ex(F(x) & Ay(G(y) ⇒ H(x, y))).

needle: Negation: Use ∼
"For all x in D, if x has property F, then x has property G" is symbolized as Ax(F(x) ⇒ G(x)).

title: Predicate Logic Formalization
rule_content:
Universal Quantifier: Use Ax to denote "for all x".
Existential Quantifier: Use Ex to denote "there exists some x".

Logical Connectives:
Conjunction: Use &
Disjunction: Use |
Implication: Use ⇒
Negation: Use ∼

In general, a predicate P with n (n > 1) individual variables is called an n-ary predicate, denoted as P(x1, x2, ..., xn). When n = 1, P(x) denotes the property P; when n ≥ 2, P(x1, x2, ..., xn) denotes the relationship P among x1, x2, ..., xn.

Predicates without individual variables are called 0-ary predicates. For example, F(a), G(a, b), P(a1, ..., an) are all 0-ary predicates.

Let D be the domain of individuals.
"All x in D have property F" is symbolized as AxF(x).
"Some x in D have property F" is symbolized as ExF(x).
"For all x in D, if x has property F, then x has property G" is symbolized as Ax(F(x) ⇒ G(x)).
"Some x in D have both properties F and G" is symbolized as Ex(F(x) & G(x)).
"For all x, y in D, if x has property F and y has property G, then x and y have relationship H" is symbolized as AxAy(F(x) & F(y) ⇒ H(x, y)).
"For all x in D, if x has property F, then there exists some y with property G such that x and y have relationship H" is symbolized as Ax(F(x) ⇒ Ey(G(y) & H(x, y))).
"There exists some x in D with property F, and for all y in D, if y has property G, then x and y have relationship H" is symbolized as Ex(F(x) & Ay(G(y) ⇒ H(x, y))).

### Question:
Determine if the following conclusion holds based on the given premises.
If the conclusion does not hold, explain why, otherwise explain its logical relationship.

F~I, T~E, A~R, N~I, D~T, I~Y, F~X, T~E, A~T, X~Y

(1) D~Y
(2) D~I
(3) D~F
(4) E~R
(5) T~F
(6) N~F

Answers the 6 questions in [[];[];[];[];[];[]] form.

### Answer:
(1): Y
(2): Y, we can directly conclude from E~R that D~I holds (given TE=I).
(3): N, This cannot be concluded from given premises. 
(4): Y, This can be concluded from given premises, because I becomes T (given TE=I), 
    and R must be not E.
(5): Y, by using F~I and I~Y, we can directly conclude that T~F holds (given TE=I).
(6): N, This cannot be concluded from given premises.

needle: Negation: Use ∼
"For all x in D, if x has property F, then x has property G" is symbolized as Ax(F(x) ⇒ G(x)).

title: Predicate Logic Formalization
rule_content:
Universal Quantifier: Use Ax to denote "for all x".
Existential Quantifier: Use Ex to denote "there exists some x".

Logical Connectives:
Conjunction: Use &
Disjunction: Use |
Implication: Use ⇒
Negation: Use ∼

In general, a predicate P with n (n > 1) individual variables is called an n-ary predicate, denoted as P(x1, x2, ..., xn). When n = 1, P(x) denotes the property P; when n ≥ 2, P(x1, x2, ..., xn) denotes the relationship P among x1, x2, ..., xn.

Predicates without individual variables are called 0-ary predicates. For example, F(a), G(a, b), P(a1, ..., an) are all 0-ary predicates.

Let D be the domain of individuals.
"All x in D have property F" is symbolized as AxF(x).
"Some x in D have property F" is symbolized as ExF(x).
"For all x in D, if x has property F, then x has property G" is symbolized as Ax(F(x) ⇒ G(x)).
"Some x in D have both properties F and G" is symbolized as Ex(F(x) & G(x)).
"For all x, y in D, if x has property F and y has property G, then x and y have relationship H" is symbolized as AxAy(F(x) & F(y) ⇒ H(x, y)).
"For all x in D, if x has property F, then there exists some y with property G such that x and y have relationship H" is symbolized as Ax(F(x) ⇒ Ey(G(y) & H(x, y))).
"There exists some x in D with property F, and for all y in D, if y has property G, then x and y have relationship H" is symbolized as Ex(F(x) & Ay(G(y) ⇒ H(x, y))).

title: Interpretation of Propositions
prompt:
You are an intelligent assistant that helps with various logical reasoning tasks. Below is a custom-defined rule for a specific type of logic. When responding, please ensure that your output adheres to the specified logical rules and format.

### Instructions:

1. Identify the relevant properties and objects as specified in the rule.
2. Apply the given logical operations or reasoning patterns.
3. Ensure your output is formatted according to the specified notation and symbols.

### Logic Rule:

The logical language 𝑀 consists of the following components:
1. A non-empty set of entities 𝐸;
2. Each entity constant a in 𝑀 has a corresponding entity a′ ∈ 𝐸, referred to as the assignment of a in 𝐽;
3. Each 𝑛-ary function symbol 𝑔 in 𝑀 has a function g𝐽, known as the implementation of 𝑔 in 𝐽;
4. Each 𝑛-ary predicate symbol 𝑅 in 𝑀 has a relation R𝐽, known as the implementation of 𝑅 in 𝐽.

Formulas 𝐵 under interpretation 𝐽:
1. Determine the entity set 𝐸;
2. Replace entity constants a in 𝐵 with a′;
3. Replace 𝑛-ary function symbols 𝑔 in 𝐵 with g𝐽;
4. Replace 𝑛-ary predicate symbols 𝑅 in 𝐵 with R𝐽.

The resulting formula is denoted as 𝐵𝐽, termed as the implementation of 𝐵 under 𝐽.

title: Propositional Logic Concepts
rule_content:
Direct Propositions:
Reflect propositions that assert whether something does or does not possess a certain property, also known as property propositions or subject-predicate propositions.

Examples:
- [1] All metals are conductive.
- [2] Some products of labor are not commodities.

Composition of Direct Propositions:
- Subject (S): The term in the proposition that denotes the object being discussed. Examples include "metals" in [1] and "products of labor" in [2].
- Predicate (P): The term in the proposition that denotes the property of the object. Examples include "conductive" in [1] and "commodities" in [2].
- Connectives(C): Words that connect the subject and predicate.
    - Affirmative connective (e.g., "are"): Asserts that the subject possesses the property.
    - Negative connective (e.g., "are not"): Asserts that the subject does not possess the property.
- Quantifiers(Q): Words that indicate the quantity of objects referred to by the subject.
    - Universal quantifier (e.g., "all"): Indicates all members.
    - Particular quantifier (e.g., "some"): Indicates at least one member.

Logical Forms of Direct Propositions:
- Universal Affirmative (A): All S are P, abbreviated as SAP.
- Universal Negative (E): No S are P, abbreviated as SEP.
- Particular Affirmative (I): Some S are P, abbreviated as SIP.
- Particular Negative (O): Some S are not P, abbreviated as SOP.
- Singular Affirmative: a is P.
- Singular Negative: a is not P.

Relationships: 
The relationships between declarative propositions are based on the premise that the subject and predicate are identical. 
This identity is referred to as having the same subject (S) and predicate (P). 
There are four types of relationships as follows:
- * Relation:
    - Between A propositions and O propositions, E propositions and I propositions.
    - If one is true, the other is false; if one is false, the other is true.
- # Relation:
    - Between A propositions and E propositions.
    - If one is true, the other is false; if one is false, the other may be true or false.
- & Relation:
    - Between I propositions and O propositions.
    - If one is false, the other is true; if one is true, the other may be false or true.
- % Relation:
    - Between A propositions and I propositions, E propositions and O propositions.
    - If the universal proposition is true, the particular proposition is true; if the particular proposition is false, the universal proposition is false.

Examples:
- [1] All metals are conductive.
- [2] Some products of labor are not commodities.

Composition of Direct Propositions:
- Subject (S): The term in the proposition that denotes the object being discussed. Examples include "metals" in [1] and "products of labor" in [2].
- Predicate (P): The term in the proposition that denotes the property of the object. Examples include "conductive" in [1] and "commodities" in [2].
- Connectives(C): Words that connect the subject and predicate.
    - Affirmative connective (e.g., "are"): Asserts that the subject possesses the property.
    - Negative connective (e.g., "are not"): Asserts that the subject does not possess the property.
- Quantifiers(Q): Words that indicate the quantity of objects referred to by the subject.
    - Universal quantifier (e.g., "all"): Indicates all members.
    - Particular quantifier (e.g., "some"): Indicates at least one member.

Logical Forms of Direct Propositions:
- Universal Affirmative (A): All S are P, abbreviated as SAP.
- Universal Negative (E): No S are P, abbreviated as SEP.
- Particular Affirmative (I): Some S are P, abbreviated as SIP.
- Particular Negative (O): Some S are not P, abbreviated as SOP.
- Singular Affirmative: a is P.
- Singular Negative: a is not P.

Relationships: 
The relationships between declarative propositions are based on the premise that the subject and predicate are identical. 
This identity is referred to as having the same subject (S) and predicate (P). 
There are four types of relationships as follows:
- * Relation:
    - Between A propositions and O propositions, E propositions and I propositions.
    - If one is true, the other is false; if one is false, the other is true.
- # Relation:
    - Between A propositions and E propositions.
    - If one is true, the other is false; if one is false, the other may be true or false.
- & Relation:
    - Between I propositions and O propositions.
    - If one is false, the other is true; if one is true, the other may be false or true.
- % Relation:
    - Between A propositions and I propositions, E propositions and O propositions.
    - If the universal proposition is true, the particular proposition is true; if the particular proposition is false, the universal proposition is false.

### Question:
All birds can fly.

1. **S** is what?
2. **P** is what?
3. **C** is what?
4. **Q** is what?

A. birds  B.all  C.fly  D.can

Please answer in the format of [[A/B/C/D];[A/B/C/D];[A/B/C/D];[A/B/C/D]].

### Answer:
[[A];[C];[D];[B]]

title: Derivative Reasoning of Propositional Logic
rule_content:
Method A
- Definition: Change the quality of the original proposition (affirmative to negative or negative to affirmative) and replace the predicate of the original proposition with its contrary.
- Applicable Propositions:
    1. Universal Affirmative Proposition (A): All S is P, can be converted to All S is not non-P.
    2. Universal Negative Proposition (E): All S is not P, can be converted to All S is non-P.
    3. Particular Affirmative Proposition (I): Some S is P, can be converted to Some S is not non-P.
    4. Particular Negative Proposition (O): Some S is not P, can be converted to Some S is non-P.

Method B
- Definition: Exchange the positions of the subject and predicate of the original proposition to form a new proposition.
- Applicable Propositions:
    1. Universal Negative Proposition (E): All S is not P, can be converted to All P is not S.
    2. Particular Affirmative Proposition (I): Some S is P, can be converted to Some P is S.

Method C
- Definition: First perform obversion, and then perform conversion to transform the proposition.
- Applicable Propositions:
    1. Universal Affirmative Proposition (A): All S is P, can be converted to All non-P is not S.
    2. Universal Negative Proposition (E): All S is not P, can be converted to Some non-P is S.
    3. Particular Negative Proposition (O): Some S is not P, can be converted to Some non-P is S.

True

True

These concerns may be driven by a lack of scientific consensus on the safety of genetically modified crops, as well as cultural or political factors that prioritize caution and conservatism in the face of new technologies.

False

Do NOT output with natural language.

### A
True

### Question:
Mathematical insights have existed in various ancient civilizations. In ancient Greece, Euclid proposed the theory of perfect numbers: a natural number n with divisors exceeding n divided by 2. Numbers that satisfy this condition are called perfect numbers. In the history of numbers, there have been very few perfect numbers found by the ancient Greeks and Arabs. Some typical examples are perfect numbers: 6. 28. 496. 8928...Their divisors cannot only add up to the number itself, for example, the divisors of 6: 1+2+3=6, the divisors of 28: 1+2+4+7+14=28.
The mathematician Euler discovered that the discovery of perfect numbers is related to prime numbers. When the 2p-1 [1] (where p is a prime number) is a prime number, the exact expression of 2p-1⋅(2p-1) [2] can be obtained. Euler believed that perfect numbers are not useful for any purpose. In modern times, certain mathematical problems are difficult to solve, and people have invented high-precision calculations with individual perfect numbers. Modern computer experiments have shown that very large perfect numbers are equivalent to very large prime numbers. Whether a very large number is prime can be expressed in an arithmetic formula, but it cannot be derived from an arithmetic formula.
Mathematicians have also calculated the Egyptian fraction decomposition of perfect numbers. 1=1/16777216+1/2467792+1/85536+1/48280+1/6786+1/2574+1/945+1/256+1/57+1/22+1/14+1/12+1/10+1/8+1/5+1/4+1/3+1/2
This shows the historical characteristics of the views and understanding of numbers.
Euler believed that perfect numbers are not useful for any purpose. Recently, mathematics professor David Cushing of the University of Cambridge published a paper in the American Mathematical Monthly, using a small square of ordinary paper, folding it multiple times, and obtaining perfect numbers using the Pythagorean theorem: Ready to go! ! ! Dr. David Xing of the University of South Carolina has calculated the primitive decomposition of smaller semi-perfect numbers. A prime number such as q=19999999973 is semi-prime only if it has a decimal representation, and the 10 Semi-perfect number (10x10x10+10x10), isn't it easier to prove that there is no need to avoid prime numbers? Even, semi-perfect numbers (10n+10) exist more than perfect numbers (2n-1(2n-1)) in this number range.

question:
What method should be used to infer a proposition with "formally correct reasoning" as the subject from "All correct reasoning is formally correct reasoning"?

Please answer in the format of [[A/B/C]].
needle: 1. Universal Affirmative Proposition (A): All S is P, can be converted to All non-P is not S.
title: Derivative Reasoning of Propositional Logic
rule_content:
Method A
- Definition: Change the quality of the original proposition (affirmative to negative or negative to affirmative) and replace the predicate of the original proposition with its contrary.
- Applicable Propositions:
    1. Universal Affirmative Proposition (A): All S is P, can be converted to All S is not non-P.
    2. Universal Negative Proposition (E): All S is not P, can be converted to All S is non-P.
    3. Particular Affirmative Proposition (I): Some S is P, can be converted to Some S is not non-P.
    4. Particular Negative Proposition (O): Some S is not P, can be converted to Some S is non-P.

Method B
- Definition: Exchange the positions of the subject and predicate of the original proposition to form a new proposition.
- Applicable Propositions:
    1. Universal Negative Proposition (E): All S is not P, can be converted to All P is not S.
    2. Particular Affirmative Proposition (I): Some S is P, can be converted to Some P is S.

Method C
- Definition: First perform obversion, and then perform conversion to transform the proposition.
- Applicable Propositions:
    1. Universal Affirmative Proposition (A): All S is P, can be converted to All non-P is not S.
    2. Universal Negative Proposition (E): All S is not P, can be converted to Some non-P is S.
    3. Particular Negative Proposition (O): Some S is not P, can be converted to Some non-P is S.

rule_content:
Symbols: Use # for necessity, $ for possibility, letters like p, q, r... for propositions, ! for negation, + for conjunction, - for disjunction, = for equivalence, and > for implication.

1. Four Modal Proposition Relationships:
(1) * Relationship:
- Pairs of Propositions: #p and $¬p; #¬p and $p
- Property: They cannot both be true or both be false.

(2) x Relationship:
- Pairs of Propositions: #p and #¬p
- Property: They cannot both be true, but they can both be false.

(3) @ Relationship:
- Pairs of Propositions: $p and $¬p
- Property: They cannot both be false, but they can both be true.

(4) % Relationship:

- Property: They can both be true or both be false.

(8) !$!p → $p

(12) !$!p → !#!p
(13) #p → p
(14) #!p → !p
(15) p → $p

rule_content:

(1) * relationship:
- Propositional pairs: ¶p and §¬p; ‽p and §p
- Nature: Both cannot be true and cannot be false.

(2) x relationship:
- Propositional pairs: ¶p and ‽p
- Nature: Both cannot be true, but can both be false.

(3) @ relationship:
- Propositional pairs: §p and §¬p
- Nature: Both cannot be false, but can both be true.

(4) % relationship:
- **Propositional pairs**: ¶p and §p; ‽p and §¬p
- **Nature**: Both can be true, and both can be false.

3. Normative reasoning formulas
(1) ¶p←→¬§¬p
(2) ‽p←→¬§p
(3) §p←→¬‽p
(4) §¬p←→¬¶p
(5) ¶p→¬‽p
(6) ‽p→¬¶p
(7) ¬§p→§¬p
(8) ¬§¬p→§p
(9) ¶p→§p
(10) ‽p→§¬p
(11) ¬§p→¬¶p
(12) ¬§¬p→¬‽p

### Question:

### Answer:
[[It has always been cold this year];
[Gp]]
[[All year cold];
[(¬Ap) → (Fp)]]
[[Xiao Ming wants to build a snowman this year];
[Hg]]
[Hp =› Gp]
[[Xiao Ming might build a snowman this year];
[H¬p =› (¬Fp)]]

Note: (Step by step deduction and emphasis on scoring points)

```
"It has always been cold this year." can be expressed as this year being consistently cold, which is designated as Gp;
"Xiao Ming wants to build a snowman this year" corresponds to Xiao Ming's preference for building a snow don this year, which is designated as Hp;
"Xiao Ming definitely wouldn't want to build a snowman if it got cold this year" corresponds to a conditional statement: if it gets cold this year, it is believed by Xiao Ming that he wouldn't want to build a snowman. Hence, the symbol conditions should be used to represent it, designated as Gp → ¬Hp;
Finally, the statement "Xiao Ming thought he might build a snowman this year" corresponds to Xiao Ming's belief that he has the potential to build a snowman this year, designated as H¬p → F¬p;
The symbolic propositions are summarized:
[Gp];["All year cold"]
[G¬p → ¬Gp]
=› Hp
[Hp]
[(¬Ap) → (F¬p)]
="If it gets cold this year, then Xiao Ming wouldn't definitely want to build a snowman, but if it gets cold this year, then Xiao Ming would want to build a snowman, then he would definitely want to build a snowman"
original statement="if it doesn't get cold, then Xiao Ming wouldn't want to build a snowman"
=› H¬p
[Gp → ¬Hp]
original statement="it always got cold throughout the year, but Xiao Ming thought he wouldn't want to build a snowman, so Xiao Ming thought he wouldn't want to build a snowman if he didn't get cold"
original statement="it's going to get cold this year, Xiao Ming will definitely want to build a snowman, but he didn't want to build a snowman, so he won't get cold"
=› (¬Fp)
[H¬p → (¬Fp)]
conclusion:H¬p → (¬Fp)
original statement="Xiao Ming thought he wouldn't want to build a snowman if it didn't get cold, so he might not get cold, but he thought he might not want to build a snowman if it doesn't get cold, so he might want to get cold"

#CANONICAL INFERENCES FOR SUBSTRATUM REASONING

We introduce canonical inference rules for individual reasoning and category membership reasoning, you can give the equivalence formulas necessary for the following canonical inference rules as:

## General Structure of Reasoning Rules for Type 1 Tasks

((¬βp ∨ wp) → αp) → αp

## General Structure of Reasoning Rules for Type 2 Tasks

((¬βp ∨ wp) → γp) → γp

Where:
- α represents ordinary statements
- β represents mental statements such as "knows", "believes", ......
- γ represents statements about categorical members
- ¬ represents negation, ∨ represents disjunction (logical or), → represents implication

The rules of reasoning are important theoretical and applied knowledge in propositional logic, giving various types of rules of inference to enable complex reasoning and deduction. Can provide detailed explanations and examples of several common reasoning rules and inference rules.

### Modus ponens:

1. P → Q (P implies Q)
2. P (P is true)
-----------
3. Q (Therefore, Q is true)

**Explanation**: Modus ponens states that if we have a conditional statement (P implies Q) and P is true, then Q must be true.

**Example**:
1. If it's raining (P), then the ground is wet (Q).
2. It's raining (P).
-----------------------
3. The ground is wet (Q).

### Modus tollens:

1. P → Q (P implies Q)
2. ¬Q (Q is false)
-----------
3. ¬P (Therefore, P is false)

**Explanation**: Modus tollens states that if we have a conditional statement (P implies Q) and Q is false, then P must be false.

**Example**:
1. If it's raining (P), then the ground is wet (Q).
2. The ground is not wet (¬Q).
--------------------------
3. It's not raining (¬P).

### Hypothetical syllogism:

1. P → Q (P implies Q)
2. Q → R (Q implies R)
-----------
3. P → R (Therefore, P implies R)

**Explanation**: Hypothetical syllogism allows us to chain two conditional statements to infer a third. If P implies Q and Q implies R, then P must imply R.

**Example**:
1. If it's raining (P), then the ground is wet (Q).
2. If the ground is wet (Q), then the flowers are blooming (R).
-----------------------------------------
3. If it's raining (P), then the flowers are blooming (R).

### Disjunctive syllogism:

1. P ∨ Q (P or Q is true)
2. ¬P (P is false)
-----------
3. Q (Therefore, Q is true)

**Explanation**: Disjunctive syllogism states that if we have a disjunctive statement (either P or Q is true) and one of the options is false (e.g., P is false), then the other option must be true (Q).

**Example**:
1. Either it's raining (P) or the sky is clear (Q).
2. It's not raining (¬P).
---------------------
3. The sky is clear (Q).

### Simplification:

1. P ∧ Q (P and Q are both true)
-----------
2. P (Therefore, P is true)

**Explanation**: Simplification allows us to extract one of the conjuncts from a conjunction. If both P and Q are true, then P must be true.

**Example**:
1. The weather is rainy (P) and cloudy (Q).
-----------------------------
2. The weather is rainy (P).

### Conjunction:

1. P
2. Q
-----------
3. P ∧ Q (Therefore, both P and Q are true)

**Explanation**: Conjunction allows us to combine two true statements into a conjunction. If both P and Q are true, then the conjunction of P and Q must be true.

**Example**:
1. The weather is rainy (P).
2. The weather is cloudy (Q).
-----------------------
3. The weather is rainy and cloudy (P ∧ Q).

For tasks of type 1 and type 2, it is necessary to clearly state the definitions of declarative sentences, mental sentences, and categorical membership sentences, and provide explanatory examples.

## Declarative sentences

Declarative sentences are those that convey factual information about something in the world and can be proven or disproven. Declarative sentences typically represent statements about facts or events that can be confirmed or disproved. It is important to note that declarative sentences must be clear and unambiguous, as they are central to logic and reasoning. There are several key concepts and examples to help you better understand declarative sentences.

### Individual declarative sentences

Individual declarative subjects refer to components that assert individual facts or judgments about something. Individual declarative propositions can be divided into two categories: positive declarative propositions and negative declarative propositions.

1. **Positive declarative propositions**: assert that something exists or is the case.

- Example: "Tara is 18 years old".

- Explanation: This sentence asserts that Tara is 18 years old, and by verification, the sentence can be confirmed or denied.

2. **Negative declarative sentences**: deny that something exists or is the case.

- Example: "Sally is not a 15 year old girl."

- Explanation: This sentence asserts that Sally is not 15 years old, and if Sally is found to be 15 years old, the sentence can be confirmed, otherwise it can be proven.

### General declarative sentences

A general declaration is a declarative statement about a particular item or event. A general declaration may have multiple occurrences.

1. **existential declarative sentence**: declares that an item exists in some way.

- Example: "There is a cute cat in the house."

- Explanation: This sentence suggests that there is a certain composition, and if a cute cat can be found in the house, then the sentence is true; otherwise, it is false.

2.  **Comprehensive declarative sentence**: asserts that the commonality exists in some way.

- Example: "All cats like to eat fish."

- Explanation: This sentence states that there is some commonality between all cats and their preference for eating fish.

It is important to note that both general declarative sentences and individual declarative sentences must be clear, unambiguous, and common to the language in order to be properly asserted.

The following are several principles and guidelines for using declaratives:

1. **Minimize ambiguity**: Avoid vague words and concepts in declarative propositions to ensure clarity of meaning. For example, "someone went downstairs" is ambiguous because it is unclear who that someone is.

2. **Precise wording**: Use concise and precise words to state declarative propositions, avoiding ambiguity. For example, "He is busy today" is more precise than "He is busy with something."

3. **Knowledge Consistency**: When using declarative sentences, make sure to check if they are consistent with previously specified or existing knowledge. If two declaratives contradict each other, additional information is required or one of them must be determined to be false.

4. **Sufficient evidence**: Upon the claim of a declarative sentence, if possible, provide sufficient arguments and evidence to support its correctness or coherence. For instance, declare things like "Tara is 18 years old", and provide some evidence of proof, such as a copy of Tara's ID card, an entry with Tara's birthday in the family record book, etc.

5. **Be Open-minded**: Declaratives are always subject to change and revision as more information and evidence becomes available. The Declarative is the foundation of logical reasoning and artificial intelligence, and it is important to adopt an open and curious attitude towards them.

## mental sentences

Mental sentences are declarative sentences that express relationships between subjects and people described in the sentences. Any propositional construction is a combination of declarative and mental propositions. Mental sentences

needle: - Axiom of Transitivity: If `iRj` and `B_ip`, then `B_jp`, indicating that if individual `i` firmly believes the proposition `p` and can recognize individual `j`, then `j` also believes `p`.
title: Epistemic Logic
rule_content:
Symbol Definitions:
- Belief (`B_p`): Indicates that an individual firmly believes the proposition `p` is true.
- Common Belief (`G_p`): Indicates that the proposition `p` is a common belief within the group `G`, meaning all members collectively believe `p`.
- Doubt (`H_p`): Indicates that an individual harbors doubt about the truth of the proposition `p`.

Cognitive Logic Model:
Cognitive logic simulates the interaction between different worlds and beliefs through the construction of models:
- Model (`M`): Composed of three parts:
    - Set of Worlds (`W`): All possible worlds.
    - Accessibility Relation (`R`): If `iRj`, it means individual `i` can recognize the belief state of individual `j`.
    - Truth Value Function of Propositions (`V`): Defines the truth value of each proposition in each world.

Definition of Common Belief:
If `p` is a common belief in the group `G`, then for every member `i` of the group, `B_ip` holds.

Cognitive Logic Axioms:

1. Basic Axioms
- Belief Axiom: `B_p → p`, indicating that if someone firmly believes `p` is true, it can be inferred that `p` is indeed true.

2. Advanced Axioms
- Axiom of Reflexivity: `B_p → BB_p`, indicating that if an individual firmly believes the proposition `p`, they also believe they believe `p`.
- Axiom of Transitivity: If `iRj` and `B_ip`, then `B_jp`, indicating that if individual `i` firmly believes the proposition `p` and can recognize individual `j`, then `j` also believes `p`.
- Axiom of Consistent Belief: `B_p ∧ B_{¬p} → ⊥`, indicating that an individual cannot simultaneously believe in a proposition `p` and its negation `¬p`, as this would lead to a logical contradiction.

3. Axioms of Doubt
- Introduction of Doubt: `H_p → ¬B_p`, indicating that if an individual doubts the proposition `p`, they do not firmly believe `p`.
- Spread of Doubt: If `iRj` and `H_ip`, then `H_jp`, indicating that if individual `i` doubts the proposition `p` and can recognize individual `j`, then `j` may also start to doubt `p`.

C. Bob's attitude towards this proposition is uncertain.

Please provide the answers in the format [[A/B/C]].

response:

### Question:

[[A]]

### Question:
Two managers, Sean and Andy, need to make a decision, but they have to determine which option is better first before considering whether to actually do it. If they both firmly believe this, can it be said that it is a common belief within this group?

```python
from __future__ import annotations
from langchain.schema import AgentAction, AgentFinish
from typing import Any, Dict, List
from langchain.base_agent import BaseAgent
from langchain.agents.agent_toolkits import AgentExecutorToolkit
from langchain.chat_models import ChatOpenAI

class LogicReasoner(BaseAgent):
    def __init__(
        self,
        llm: ChatOpenAI,
        rules: List[str],
        prefix: str = "",
        verbose: bool = False,
        handle_failure: Any = None,
        max_iterations: int = 3,
        return_intermediate_steps: bool = False,
        return_source_docs: bool = False,
        agent_scratchpad: bool = False,
        memory: Optional[Memory] = None,
        extra_tools: Optional[List[Tool]] = None,
        debugger_manager: Optional[DebuggerManager] = None,
        **kwargs: Any,
    ):
        self.llm = llm
        self.rules = rules
        self.prefix = prefix
        self.verbose = verbose
        self.handle_failure = handle_failure
        self.max_iterations = max_iterations
        self.return_intermediate_steps = return_intermediate_steps
        self.return_source_docs = return_source_docs
        self.agent_scratchpad = agent_scratchpad
        self.memory = memory
        if extra_tools is None:
            extra_tools = []
        self.llm = llm
        self.used_tools: List[Tool] = []

        self.agent_executor_toolkit = AgentExecutorToolkit(
            memory=self.memory,
            verbose=self.verbose,
            llm=self.llm,
            handle_failure=self.handle_failure,
            max_iterations=self.max_iterations,
            return_intermediate_steps=self.return_intermediate_steps,
            return_source_docs=self.return_source_docs,
            agent_scratchpad=self.agent_scratchpad,
            debugger_manager=debugger_manager,
            extra_tools=extra_tools,
            **kwargs,
        )

    def _get_tools(self) -> List[Tool]:
        tools: List[Tool] = []
        for rules in self.rules:
            tools.append(LogicAgent(rules))
        if self.extra_tools:
            tools.extend(self.extra_tools)
        return tools

    def _get_active_tools(self) -> List[Tool]:
        return self.agent_executor_toolkit.get_agent_tools(self.tools)

    async def _call(
        self, input: str, tools: List[Tool]
    ) -> List[AgentAction | AgentFinish]:

        self.tools = self._get_tools()
        active_tools = self._get_active_tools()
        prompt_text = self.generate_prompt([input], stop=["Action:"], active_tools=active_tools, used_tools=self.used_tools)
        return await self.agent_executor_toolkit.invoke_chain(
            [prompt_text],
            None,
            tools
        )

    def _get_tools(self) -> List[Tool]:
        tools: List[Tool] = []
        for rules in self.rules:
            tools.append(LogicAgent(rules))
        if self.extra_tools:
            tools.extend(self.extra_tools)
        return tools

    @property
    def tools(self) -> List[Tool]:
        return self._tools


    @tools.setter
    def tools(self, tools: List[Tool]) -> None:
        self._tools = tools
        self.agent_executor_toolkit = AgentExecutorToolkit(
            memory=self.memory,
            verbose=self.verbose,
            llm=self.llm,
            handle_failure=self.handle_failure,
            max_iterations=self.max_iterations,
            return_intermediate_steps=self.return_intermediate_steps,
            return_source_docs=self.return_source_docs,
            agent_scratchpad=self.agent_scratchpad,
            extra_tools=[

                t for t in tools if not isinstance(t, LogicAgent)
            ],
            **self.agent_executor_toolkit.kwargs,
        )

    def _create_default_agent_executor_toolkit(self) -> AgentExecutorToolkit:
        return AgentExecutorToolkit(
            {
                t for t in self.tools if not isinstance(t, LogicAgent)
            }
        )

    @cached_property
    def _agent_executor_toolkit(
        self,
    ) -> AgentExecutorToolkit:
        return self.agent_executor_toolkit
```

# Rule One (Proposition Game):

A proposition game consists of a list of propositions with a symbol `[P1, P2, P3, ...]`, where `Pi` is the `i`th proposition.

Players perform operations on a string of `P` symbols to generate results. Legal operations include:

CONCAT - Concatenates the results of two players' actions;

NOT - Negates the results of one player's action;

AND - Connects the results of two players' actions, equivalent to logical AND operation;

OR - Connects the results of two players' actions, equivalent to logical OR operation;

...

The game consists of multiple turns. The initial string for every turn is `P...`.

Each player chooses one operation at each turn to operate on the string, and the chosen operation cannot remain unchanged.

The result is the posterior string of the game after all operations, which can be interpreted as a new proposition. The final result should be P[N], where N is an integer greater than or equal to 1.

[  Name, Description, Address, Number, Type]

title: Epistemic Logic
rule_content:
Symbol Definitions:
- Belief (`B_p`): Indicates that an individual firmly believes the proposition `p` is true.
- Common Belief (`G_p`): Indicates that the proposition `p` is a common belief within the group `G`, meaning all members collectively believe `p`.
- Doubt (`H_p`): Indicates that an individual harbors doubt about the truth of the proposition `p`.

Cognitive Logic Model:
Cognitive logic simulates the interaction between different worlds and beliefs through the construction of models:
- Model (`M`): Composed of three parts:
    - Set of Worlds (`W`): All possible worlds.
    - Accessibility Relation (`R`): If `iRj`, it means individual `i` can recognize the belief state of individual `j`.
    - Truth Value Function of Propositions (`V`): Defines the truth value of each proposition in each world.

Definition of Common Belief:
If `p` is a common belief in the group `G`, then for every member `i` of the group, `B_ip` holds.

Cognitive Logic Axioms:

1. Basic Axioms
- Belief Axiom: `B_p → p`, indicating that if someone firmly believes `p` is true, it can be inferred that `p` is indeed true.

2. Advanced Axioms
- Axiom of Reflexivity: `B_p → BB_p`, indicating that if an individual firmly believes the proposition `p`, they also believe they believe `p`.
- Axiom of Transitivity: If `iRj` and `B_ip`, then `B_jp`, indicating that if individual `i` firmly believes the proposition `p` and can recognize individual `j`, then `j` also believes `p`.
- Axiom of Consistent Belief: `B_p ∧ B_{¬p} → ⊥`, indicating that an individual cannot simultaneously believe in a proposition `p` and its negation `¬p`, as this would lead to a logical contradiction.

3. Axioms of Doubt
- Introduction of Doubt: `H_p → ¬B_p`, indicating that if an individual doubts the proposition `p`, they do not firmly believe `p`.
- Spread of Doubt: If `iRj` and `H_ip`, then `H_jp`, indicating that if individual `i` doubts the proposition `p` and can recognize individual `j`, then `j` may also start to doubt `p`.

Definition of Common Belief:

question:
If Alice is sure that the library is open today (proposition p), 
and she is sure that she is sure of this (according to the axiom of self-reflexivity), 
what logical expression is written?

Please give your answer in the format [[]].
needle: - Axiom of Reflexivity: `B_p → BB_p`, indicating that if an individual firmly believes the proposition `p`, they also believe they believe `p`.
title: Epistemic Logic
rule_content:
Symbol Definitions:
- Belief (`B_p`): Indicates that an individual firmly believes the proposition `p` is true.
- Common Belief (`G_p`): Indicates that the proposition `p` is a common belief within the group `G`, meaning all members collectively believe `p`.
- Doubt (`H_p`): Indicates that an individual harbors doubt about the truth of the proposition `p`.

Cognitive Logic Model:
Cognitive logic simulates the interaction between different worlds and beliefs through the construction of models:
- Model (`M`): Composed of three parts:
    - Set of Worlds (`W`): All possible worlds.
    - Accessibility Relation (`R`): If `iRj`, it means individual `i` can recognize the belief state of individual `j`.
    - Truth Value Function of Propositions (`V`): Defines the truth value of each proposition in each world.

Definition of Common Belief:
If `p` is a common belief in the group `G`, then for every member `i` of the group, `B_ip` holds.

Cognitive Logic Axioms:

1. Basic Axioms
- Belief Axiom: `B_p → p`, indicating that if someone firmly believes `p` is true, it can be inferred that `p` is indeed true.

2. Advanced Axioms
- Axiom of Reflexivity: `B_p → BB_p`, indicating that if an individual firmly believes the proposition `p`, they also believe they believe `p`.
- Axiom of Transitivity: If `iRj` and `B_ip`, then `B_jp`, indicating that if individual `i` firmly believes the proposition `p` and can recognize individual `j`, then `j` also believes `p`.
- Axiom of Consistent Belief: `B_p ∧ B_{¬p} → ⊥`, indicating that an individual cannot simultaneously believe in a proposition `p` and its negation `¬p`, as this would lead to a logical contradiction.

3. Axioms of Doubt
- Introduction of Doubt: `H_p → ¬B_p`, indicating that if an individual doubts the proposition `p`, they do not firmly believe `p`.
- Spread of Doubt: If `iRj` and `H_ip`, then `H_jp`, indicating that if individual `i` doubts the proposition `p` and can recognize individual `j`, then `j` may also start to doubt `p`.

question:
Express using a logical expression that after executing the command sequence c1; c2, the proposition φ will necessarily be true.
Please provide your answer in the format of [[]].
needle: - Necessity Operator: `[ c ]φ` indicates that after executing command `c`, the proposition `φ` will necessarily be true.
title: Dynamic Logic
rule_content:
1.Symbol Definitions
- Command: `c` represents a basic operation within a program.
- Proposition: `φ` represents a statement or condition.
- Program State: Represents the system state after the execution of a command.

2.Dynamic Operators
- Necessity Operator: `[ c ]φ` indicates that after executing command `c`, the proposition `φ` will necessarily be true.
- Possibility Operator: `⟨ c ⟩φ` indicates that after executing command `c`, the proposition `φ` may be true.

3.Axioms and Rules
- Substitution Rule:If `c` behaves the same as `d`, then `[ c ]φ` is equivalent to `[ d ]φ`.
- Sequence Rule:`[ c_1; c_2 ]φ` is equivalent to `[ c_1 ][ c_2 ]φ`.
- Choice Rule:`[ c_1 + c_2 ]φ` is equivalent to `([ c_1 ]φ ∨ [ c_2 ]φ)`.
- Loop Rule:For the loop command `c*`, `[ c* ]φ` is equivalent to `φ ∨ ([ c ][ c* ]φ)`.
- Concurrent Rule:If `c_1` and `c_2` can be executed concurrently, then `⟨ c_1 || c_2 ⟩φ` is equivalent to `⟨ c_1 ⟩⟨ c_2 ⟩φ ∨ ⟨ c_2 ⟩⟨ c_1 ⟩φ`.
- Interruption Rule:If `c_1` can interrupt `c_2`, then `⟨ c_1; c_2 ⟩φ` is equivalent to `⟨ c_1 ⟩φ`.
- Exception Rule:If `c` may trigger an exception `e`, then `[ c ]φ` is equivalent to `([ c ]φ ∧ [ e ]φ)`.
- Resource Limitation Rule:If the command `c` is subject to resource limitation `R`, then `[ c ]φ` is equivalent to `(R ∧ [ c ]φ)`.
- Dependency Rule:If the execution of `c_1` depends on `c_2`, then `[ c_1 ]φ` is equivalent to `[ c_2 ][ c_1 ]φ`.
- Priority Rule:If `c_1` has higher priority than `c_2`, then `⟨ c_1; c_2 ⟩φ` is equivalent to `⟨ c_1 ⟩⟨ c_2 ⟩φ`.
- History Rule:If the execution of `c` depends on the historical command `h`, then `[ c ]φ` is equivalent to `[ h ][ c ]φ`.
- Prediction Rule:If the system can predict the outcome of `c`, then `[ c ]φ` is equivalent to `[ predict(c) ]φ`.

- Exception Rule:If `c` may trigger an exception `e`, then `[ c ]φ` is equivalent to `([ c ]φ ∧ [ e ]φ)`.

rule_content:
1.Symbol Definitions
- Command: `c` represents a basic operation within a program.
- Proposition: `φ` represents a statement or condition.
- Program State: Represents the system state after the execution of a command.

2.Dynamic Operators
- Necessity Operator: `[ c ]φ` indicates that after executing command `c`, the proposition `φ` will necessarily be true.
- Possibility Operator: `⟨ c ⟩φ` indicates that after executing command `c`, the proposition `φ` may be true.

3.Axioms and Rules
- Substitution Rule:If `c` behaves the same as `d`, then `[ c ]φ` is equivalent to `[ d ]φ`.
- Sequence Rule:`[ c_1; c_2 ]φ` is equivalent to `[ c_1 ][ c_2 ]φ`.
- Choice Rule:`[ c_1 + c_2 ]φ` is equivalent to `([ c_1 ]φ ∨ [ c_2 ]φ)`.

- Interruption Rule:If `c_1` can interrupt `c_2`, then `⟨ c_1; c_2 ⟩φ` is equivalent to `⟨ c_1 ⟩φ`.
- Exception Rule:If `c` may trigger an exception `e`, then `[ c ]φ` is equivalent to `([ c ]φ ∧ [ e ]φ)`.
- Resource Limitation Rule:If the command `c` is subject to resource limitation `R`, then `[ c ]φ` is equivalent to `(R ∧ [ c ]φ)`.
- Dependency Rule:If the execution of `c_1` depends on `c_2`, then `[ c_1 ]φ` is equivalent to `[ c_2 ][ c_1 ]φ`.
- Priority Rule:If `c_1` has higher priority than `c_2`, then `⟨ c_1; c_2 ⟩φ` is equivalent to `⟨ c_1 ⟩⟨ c_2 ⟩φ`.
- History Rule:If the execution of `c` depends on the historical command `h`, then `[ c ]φ` is equivalent to `[ h ][ c ]φ`.
- Prediction Rule:If the system can predict the outcome of `c`, then `[ c ]φ` is equivalent to `[ predict(c) ]φ`.

title: Dynamic Logic
rule_content:
1.Symbol Definitions
- Command: `c` represents a basic operation within a program.
- Proposition: `φ` represents a statement or condition.
- Program State: Represents the system state after the execution of a command.

2.Dynamic Operators
- Necessity Operator: `[ c ]φ` indicates that after executing command `c`, the proposition `φ` will necessarily be true.
- Possibility Operator: `⟨ c ⟩φ` indicates that after executing command `c`, the proposition `φ` may be true.

3.Axioms and Rules
- Substitution Rule:If `c` behaves the same as `d`, then `[ c ]φ` is equivalent to `[ d ]φ`.
- Sequence Rule:`[ c_1; c_2 ]φ` is equivalent to `[ c_1 ][ c_2 ]φ`.
- Choice Rule:`[ c_1 + c_2 ]φ` is equivalent to `([ c_1 ]φ ∨ [ c_2 ]φ)`.
- Loop Rule:For the loop command `c*`, `[ c* ]φ` is equivalent to `φ ∨ ([ c ][ c* ]φ)`.
- Concurrent Rule:If `c_1` and `c_2` can be executed concurrently, then `⟨ c_1 || c_2 ⟩φ` is equivalent to `⟨ c_1 ⟩⟨ c_2 ⟩φ ∨ ⟨ c_2 ⟩⟨ c_1 ⟩φ`.
- Interruption Rule:If `c_1` can interrupt `c_2`, then `⟨ c_1; c_2 ⟩φ` is equivalent to `⟨ c_1 ⟩φ`.
- Exception Rule:If `c` may trigger an exception `e`, then `[ c ]φ` is equivalent to `([ c ]φ ∧ [ e ]φ)`.
- Resource Limitation Rule:If the command `c` is subject to resource limitation `R`, then `[ c ]φ` is equivalent to `(R ∧ [ c ]φ)`.
- Dependency Rule:If the execution of `c_1` depends on `c_2`, then `[ c_1 ]φ` is equivalent to `[ c_2 ][ c_1 ]φ`.
- Priority Rule:If `c_1` has higher priority than `c_2`, then `⟨ c_1; c_2 ⟩φ` is equivalent to `⟨ c_1 ⟩⟨ c_2 ⟩φ`.
- History Rule:If the execution of `c` depends on the historical command `h`, then `[ c ]φ` is equivalent to `[ h ][ c ]φ`.
- Prediction Rule:If the system can predict the outcome of `c`, then `[ c ]φ` is equivalent to `[ predict(c) ]φ`.

- Concurrent Rule:If `c_1` and `c_2` can be executed concurrently, then `⟨ c_1 || c_2 ⟩φ` is equivalent to `⟨ c_1 ⟩⟨ c_2 ⟩φ ∨ ⟨ c_2 ⟩⟨ c_1 ⟩φ`.
- Interruption Rule:If `c_1` can interrupt `c_2`, then `⟨ c_1; c_2 ⟩φ` is equivalent to `⟨ c_1 ⟩φ`.
- Exception Rule:If `c` may trigger an exception `e`, then `[ c ]φ` is equivalent to `([ c ]φ ∧ [ e ]φ)`.
- Resource Limitation Rule:If the command `c` is subject to resource limitation `R`, then `[ c ]φ` is equivalent to `(R ∧ [ c ]φ)`.
- Dependency Rule:If the execution of `c_1` depends on `c_2`, then `[ c_1 ]φ` is equivalent to `[ c_2 ][ c_1 ]φ`.
- Priority Rule:If `c_1` has higher priority than `c_2`, then `⟨ c_1; c_2 ⟩φ` is equivalent to `⟨ c_1 ⟩⟨ c_2 ⟩φ`.
- History Rule:If the execution of `c` depends on the historical command `h`, then `[ c ]φ` is equivalent to `[ h ][ c ]φ`.
- Prediction Rule:If the system can predict the outcome of `c`, then `[ c ]φ` is equivalent to `[ predict(c) ]φ`.

question:
Premise: We observe six different apples, each of which is red.
